speaker: Roger
text: [_v.o._] Well, I had a really good year.  I decided hey, why not reward myself?  So I bought what I really wanted - a forty- eight foot cabin cruiser.  Want to know how much it cost me? I'll tell you how much it cost me: three hundred grand, not to mention the twenty thou for the custom teak decking.  Now, here's my problem: the wife wants to call this incredible vessel _Lulubelle_ , after her mother.  _Lulubelle_!  So I say, "no, we call it the _Intrepid_."  So what do you think it should be called?  _Lulubelle_ or the _Intrepid_?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_after a beat_] Roger, at Cornell University they have an incredible piece of scientific equipment known as the tunneling electron microscope.  Now, this microscope is so powerful that by firing electrons you can actually see images of the atom, the infinitesimally minute building blocks of our universe. Roger, if I were using that microscope right now... I still wouldn't be able to locate my interest in your problem.  Thank you for your call.

speaker: Frasier
text: And now, [_reading_] "Hungry for Chinese tonight?  I always"... Uh, I'm sorry, I just - we're experiencing technical difficulties.  Let's go to a pre-recorded commercial message.

speaker: Frasier
text: Roz, why did you hand me this copy?  I don't do personal endorsements.

speaker: Roz
text: What is the big deal?  All the other personalities do them.

speaker: Frasier
text: The other personalities aren't doctors.  If I allow myself to become a common pitchman, I lose all my credibility.  I am a wise man, a shaman.

speaker: Roz
text: Zip up your fly, wise man.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Whoa, Doc!  This is a radio studio, not a bus terminal.

speaker: Frasier
text: Look who's here, Roz.  Noel Coward.

speaker: Roz
text: Listen Bulldog, I hate to mix business with revulsion, but Frasier, as usual, will not do this promo...

speaker: Bulldog
text: Love to. [_snatches copy from Roz_]

speaker: Roz
text: Great.  I need it done now.

speaker: Bulldog
text: No problem.  Doc, doc, with all due respect, you're an idiot. These promos are easy money.

speaker: Frasier
text: The money is irrelevant.  It's a question of integrity.

speaker: Bulldog
text: Integrity? [_raps on Frasier's forehead_] Hello?  We're talking liver snacks for the Bulldog. [_goes into recording booth_]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_reading a piece of paper from Roz's desk_] What is this with my name on it here, Roz?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, that's the contract for the "Hunan Palace" gig.  It's how much they were going to pay you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Wow.

speaker: Roz
text: I guess I need to have them change the name on here to Bulldog's.

speaker: Frasier
text: They pay you that much money just to read some copy?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah.  Of course, Bulldog usually adds his own special touch. _Bulldog bangs his little gong, then reads the copy over the air, with a BAD, stereotypical Chinese accent._

speaker: Bulldog
text: Aww, so you come chop-chop to "Hoo-nan Parace," where Pekin' duck is awrays extla clispy! _He emphasizes "clispy duck" by crinkling a sheet of cellophane into the mike, and then blowing a duck call.  As Frasier and Roz stare in disgust, he raises his arms proudly._

speaker: Roz
text: [_to Frasier_] We're gonna get sued this time, for sure. **WOULD YOU BUY AN EGGROLL FROM THIS MAN?**  _Scene Two - Frasier's Apartment. Martin and Daphne are sorting out some photos.  Frasier enters._

speaker: Frasier
text: Damn it! I just put a dent in my front bumper when I pulled into my parking space.  Does anybody know what happened to that tennis ball I hung over my space so I wouldn't pull up too far?  _On cue, Eddie pads up to Frasier and drops the ball at his feet, so it can be thrown again._

speaker: Martin
text: He was bored, he needed a toy.  Hey, go ahead and throw it, he'll run and get it for you.  _Frasier picks up the ball, goes to the balcony and throws it over the edge, inviting Eddie to fetch._

speaker: Martin
text: He didn't think that was funny, and he knows where you sleep.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, Daphne, a situation has arisen over at work and uh, I'm not sure how it should be handled.  I was hoping maybe your objective viewpoint could uh, be helpful.

speaker: Martin
text: Sure, shoot.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, what would you think if I did a commercial and publicly endorsed a product?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, you mean like Cher does?

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you Daphne, one against.  Dad?

speaker: Martin
text: What's the product?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, the station wanted me to do a commercial for a Chinese restaurant.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, what's the problem?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I hold a position of trust in this community, and people do what I tell them to, and I would hate to be accused of abusing that position.  The thought of a doctor selling things is kind of distasteful, don't you think?

speaker: Daphne
text: What about Dr. Sneezy's cold medicine?

speaker: Frasier
text: Dr. Sneezy is a cartoon character.  The fact that he's a giant purple hippopotamus should have probably tipped you off.

speaker: Martin
text: I say take the money and run.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, I'm tempted, if for no other reason than to keep Bulldog from further alienating the Asian-American community.  I just want to make sure I don't compromise my principles.

speaker: Daphne
text: Dr. Crane, you've dedicated your live to helping people, haven't you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, yes.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, suppose one of your listeners was in a quandary over where to buy good Chinese food?  Wouldn't your commercial be helping them?

speaker: Martin
text: Look, why don't you just go down there?  If you like the food do the commercial, if you don't, don't.

speaker: Frasier
text: I suppose that's the logical approach.  Why don't the three of us go tonight?  I'll make a call.  Oh, I'd better make the reservations under a different name, I don't want any special treatment, you know. [_dials_] I want them - I just want to be treated like an average working Joe. [_into phone_] Good evening... Yes... yes, we'd like a reservation for three this evening at eight.  Oh, nothing 'til ten?  Oh, well then, ah, this is Dr. Frasier Crane... from the radio, and ah... Yes, I thought you might.  Thank you. [_hangs up_] We're in at 9:45.  _FADE TO:  Scene Three - The radio station. Frasier is finishing off his commercial._

speaker: Frasier
text: Did I say tasty?  Tasty doesn't do justice to those succulent pot-stickers.  And the kung pao chicken - ooh, don't get me started.  "So if you've got a yen for Chinese tonight, hurry on down to the Hunan Palace."  Well, that's it for today. This is Dr. Frasier Crane hoping we'll see you tomorrow, on KACL 780 AM.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know Roz, I think I'm getting the knack for doing these promos.  Did you hear that little ad-lib I did about the "yen" for Chinese food?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah.  By the way, "yen" is Japanese, not Chinese.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well... Did I tell you, I got a call from the owners of the Hunan Palace the other day, they said that since I started doing these commercials their business had gone up by 30 percent.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, isn't that what advertising is supposed to do?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes it is, Miss Sour-Britches, give me a little credit.  My God, I've pleased the boys upstairs, I've gotten perfect strangers to try a new restaurant, and most importantly, I've helped a struggling immigrant family who came to these shores a mere twelve years ago, with nothing more than a dream, a few recipes, and a wok.

speaker: Bebe
text: Dr. Crane?  What a privilege this is.

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me?

speaker: Bebe
text: Bebe Glaser.  I'm Bulldog Briscoe's agent.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah.  Ah, well.  Pleasure meeting you.

speaker: Bebe
text: Listen.  I'm not usually this forward, but I'm going to come right out and say it.  I've done some research and I know you're not represented by anyone, how would you feel about signing on with me as a client?  If your answer is no, it won't hurt my feelings.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I really don't think so.

speaker: Bebe
text: [_sorrowfully_] Why?

speaker: Frasier
text: It's not that I'm not flattered, Miss Glaser, but umm... you see, I'm not really a radio personality per se.

speaker: Bebe
text: Oh come on, Dr. Crane, I've heard those spots you've done for that Chinese restaurant, you make me want to stuff my face full of egg rolls and... I don't know what.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you.  Uh... but I, you see, I dine at the Hunan Palace frequently, and uh, that's the only reason I did those commercials.

speaker: Bebe
text: The last thing I would ever want you to do is to advertise something you don't believe in.  I am an agent, not a pimp.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I don't mean to offend...

speaker: Bebe
text: Are you kidding?  You're terrific, you can't offend me.  Let me just leave you with my card.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I really don't think that's necessary.

speaker: Bebe
text: [_snatches card back_] Give me back my card.  I will not let you call me.  It is too refreshing to meet someone who isn't seduced by the almighty dollar.  I would refuse your call. [_checks watch_] Ah, I've got to go.  Flying to Palo Alto, my daughter's at Stanford. [_starts to leave_] Ah, wait.  You don't have kids, do you?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well yes, I have a five year-old son.

speaker: Bebe
text: Lucky you, you won't have to worry about it for years. [_starts to leave again_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Worry about what?

speaker: Bebe
text: [_returns_] Tuition, innocent.  Oh wait, I see.  You're going to send him to a state college.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well no, no.  I plan to send him to my alma mater, Harvard.

speaker: Bebe
text: Ouch!  Kiss it and make it better.  Have you seen Business Week's projection for college costs in the year 2010? [_gives a small, high pitched squeal_] Oh!  I've got to go, that plane is not going to wait for little Bebe. [_walks off again_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know, maybe we should talk, sometime.

speaker: Bebe
text: Let's talk now. [_comes back_] I think I can die peacefully without seeing the first half of the Stanford-Cal game. [_they walk off arm in arm_]

speaker: Frasier
text: You see, it's not that I object to doing commercials, it's just that I would have to try a product first before I could endorse it.

speaker: Bebe
text: Dr. Crane, I wouldn't have it any other way.  **THAT BETTER BE YOUR FOOT**  _Scene Four - A bathroom showroom. Frasier, Daphne and Martin are in swimming costumes, sitting in a Jacuzzi._

speaker: Martin
text: Tell me again why I'm here?

speaker: Frasier
text: Because if I do the commercial I have to say that my friends and family enjoy this, and I won't say it unless it's true.

speaker: Daphne
text: I feel kind of silly sitting here in the showroom.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well I apologize for that, but it's the best place to try one. So, tell me the truth.  Aren't you two enjoying this?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I do like the bubbles.  It's a little like sitting in hot champagne.  Not that I've done that very much.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, did you know that this unit is made from the same heat resistant space-age polymer that's used on the NASA space shuttles?

speaker: Martin
text: Great.  Next time I'm re-entering the earth's atmosphere in a hot tub I won't have to worry.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well?  Do you like it?

speaker: Martin
text: ...I have to admit, it's making my hip feel a little better.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's all I needed to hear.  My friends like it, my family likes it - I like it.  I can do the commercial and Frederick can go to Harvard. [_a man walks into the showroom_] Oh my god! Isn't that Dave Hendler from our building?  You know, he's the head of the Seattle Psychiatric Association.

speaker: Daphne
text: That's not Dave Hendler.

speaker: Martin
text: Shh, don't worry about it.  Enjoy the quiet while you can.  _END OF ACT ONE  ACT TWO_  **780 AM ON YOUR RADIO DIAL**  _Scene Five - Frasier's Apartment. Frasier, Daphne and Martin are listening to a recording of his advert._

speaker: Advert
text: ...soothing bubbles, bubbles that will ease your aching body. This is Dr. Frasier Crane.  In these pressure-packed times, what could be better that a warm, relaxing dip in a Renwood hot tub?  Let Renwood's patented Ultra-Blow air system surround your body.  My family and friends like it...

speaker: Daphne
text: [_to Martin_] That's us.

speaker: Advert
text: ...and you'll like it too.  And if you act quickly, you'll receive a complimentary scum guard.  So hurry down to your Redwood Hot-tub dealer.  Say Frasier Crane sent you.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_turns off recording_] Well?  What do you think?

speaker: Daphne
text: I could almost smell the chlorine.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad?  How about you?

speaker: Martin
text: [_leaving_] I liked it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Really?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  I liked it.

speaker: Frasier
text: You really, really like it?

speaker: Martin
text: No, I liked it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, what was wrong with it?

speaker: Martin
text: Nothing.

speaker: Frasier
text: You hated it, didn't you?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah.  Goodnight, Frasier. [_exits_]

speaker: Bebe
text: Hello, darling. [_enters_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Bebe.

speaker: Bebe
text: First off, _mea culpa_ for dropping by unannounced, but you are going to kiss me when you hear what I've done for you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh... hello.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hi.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no no no no no.  Bebe, this is Daphne Moon, my father's physical therapist. [_Bebe laughs, as if to say "the very idea."_] Well, I believe I was about to kiss you for something.

speaker: Bebe
text: Well, today I got a very attractive offer for you to be a product spokesman, and we know they're serious because it's pay or play.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ooh... [__he says to cover his bafflement__]

speaker: Daphne
text: That's the best kind.  You get your money whether you do it or not.

speaker: Bebe
text: Well, listen to this one.

speaker: Frasier
text: How do you know that?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, I must confess, there is a chapter of my life I haven't told you or your father about.  Back when I was twelve, I starred in a television show in England.  Well, I'll leave you to your business. [_makes to escape_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, Daphne, just get back here.  You what?

speaker: Daphne
text: I starred in a TV series.  It was quite popular in its day, maybe you've heard of it?  "Mind Your Knickers"?  It was about a group of high-spirited, ethnically diverse twelve-year-olds in a girls' private boarding school.  I played Emma, the short, spunky one.  Of course, by the end of the series, I was sixteen, five foot ten, and they had me boozies bound up tighter than a mummy.  Well, I'm off. [_leaves_]

speaker: Frasier
text: The woman is like an artichoke.  You just peel away one astounding leaf after another.  Well anyway, back to business. What have you got for me?

speaker: Bebe
text: [_producing tin of nuts_] Voila.  Emery's Nuts.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, dear.  Oh, I can't endorse these.

speaker: Bebe
text: Why not?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, for one thing I don't like them, and they're sixty percent fat, they're laced with salt and they wreak havoc with my diverticulitis.

speaker: Bebe
text: Of course they do, they're nuts.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm sorry, I'm afraid I can't.

speaker: Bebe
text: Well... then I will just tell them they can take their five figure deal and find someone else.

speaker: Frasier
text: Five figures?

speaker: Bebe
text: Didn't I mention, precious?  This is for television, the big kahuna.

speaker: Frasier
text: Television?

speaker: Bebe
text: Well, I understand if you have a problem.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well I-I... I don't mean to be difficult, I do have my standards, you know?  I only endorse things that I like or... or I think are therapeutic, like the hot-tub.

speaker: Bebe
text: Let me pinch you, you're not real!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well...

speaker: Bebe
text: But still, I... I wonder if you're not being the tiniest bit shortsighted.  Research has shown that a single television commercial can turn an obscure radio personality into a national celebrity... a year from now, someone like you could be broadcasting your message of hope and healing not just to the Pacific Northwest, but to the entire nation.  But of course, there's not much I can [_opening tin_] do about it if you [_slides tin over to Frasier_] don't like the product.  _Frasier slowly picks up the tin and forces himself to eat a nut.  FADE TO:_ **THE BIG KAHUNA**  _Scene Six - Television studio. Frasier is sitting in front of the makeup mirror with Bebe. He has two paper tissues round his neck, to protect his collar._

speaker: Frasier
text: I've never been one hundred percent happy with my nose.

speaker: Bebe
text: You can't be serious.  That's a nose people trust.

speaker: Bebe
text: Finally, a script.  Thanks, Jeff. [_hands it to Frasier_] Seen it already, you're going to love it.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_reading_] "Two nuts are arguing with each other."  That's cute. "�I'm a nut.' �No, I'm a nut!'" Ha, that's funny.  Ah... "�Hold it, you're both nuts.  I'm Dr. Frasier Crane, noted psychiatrist, and I know a nut when I see one.'"  Hmm, I just, I don't know abut that line.

speaker: Bebe
text: Oh, what's wrong?  It's a scream.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but it... it may be a scream, but it, it's... what's the word I'm looking for?

speaker: Bebe
text: What?  "Tuition?!"  "Retirement beach house?!" [_calms down_] I'm so sorry.  I'm so sorry, it's just that I want so much for you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Bebe, I don't want to get a reputation for being difficult, but I... I'm just not comfortable with this line.

speaker: Bebe
text: Frasier?  Frasier, Frasier.  How long have we been together?

speaker: Frasier
text: Six days.

speaker: Bebe
text: Do you think I would ever have you do something that you were uncomfortable with?  What makes this so wonderful is that you're spoofing yourself, you're showing that psychiatrists can be loose, you're making shrinks more accessible to the average person.

speaker: Frasier
text: So what you're saying is that I would be doing psychiatry a service by doing this commercial?

speaker: Bebe
text: You have a way of cutting through the baloney that knocks me out cold.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_reading_] Oh, dear.  What does this mean?  "Frasier comes out of his shell."  _Bebe notices two stagehands pulling on set a giant monkey nut, and swivels Frasier's chair round so he can't see it, B.S.-ing as she does so._

speaker: Bebe
text: It is a... technical term.  It's a light... a lighting thing. You, you see, you come out of your shadow, or your shell, into the light.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_in awe_] I have so much to learn about this business. **KNEES TOGETHER, LIPS APART**  _Scene Seven - Cafe Nervosa. Niles is sitting at a table when Frasier rushes in.  He still has the tissues around his neck._

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh Niles, Niles, thanks for meeting me, I have to talk to you about something.

speaker: Niles
text: Why do you have that ridiculous tissue around your neck?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, they didn't tell me I could take it off, so I kept it on.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, silly me.  Here I thought it was just a means to attract attention, to have people come up to you and say, "Are you an actor?" thus affording you the opportunity to say yes, you are indeed an actor, and then proceed to crow, gloat and strut in a way you could not otherwise do.

speaker: Frasier
text: And the reason you have "SHRINK" on your license plate would be...?  Niles, listen.  I've got to do this commercial in half an hour and... I just don't think I can go through with it, I'm afraid that I'm compromising my integrity as a psychiatrist.

speaker: Niles
text: Why do you feel like that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, for one thing my co-stars are dressed up as an almond and a walnut.  Now listen Niles, I've... I need your guidance.

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, I don't see this as a problem.

speaker: Frasier
text: You don't think this is the selling out of Frasier Crane?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, certainly not.  You sold out a long time ago.  You know, the moment you agreed to do that call-in show, you sold out.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Niles.  You are such a purist.  Granted, I can't do the kind of in-depth analysis one can with a single patient, but my show helps literally thousands of people a day.

speaker: Niles
text: Let's face it, Frasier, you talk about wanting to safeguard your professional dignity, but the first time you went on the air, you got out of medicine and into showbiz.  You're no different from that movie star who let everybody look up her skirt in that film, and then did nothing but complain that nobody took her seriously as an actress.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that has nothing to do with this!

speaker: Niles
text: Have you seen that movie?  Maris and I rented the video and, I don't mind telling you, we pushed our beds together that night! [_pause_] And that was no mean feat.  Her room, as you know, is across the hall.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, will you just tell me, would you do it?

speaker: Niles
text: A nude scene?  I suppose if it were integral to the plot...

speaker: Frasier
text: Not a nude scene!  Would you do this commercial?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, certainly not, I'm a respected psychiatrist. [_looks at watch, then stands_]

speaker: Frasier
text: So what you're saying is that I shouldn't do it.

speaker: Niles
text: No, no no no.  I'm saying it doesn't matter.  Let's face it, Frasier - they've already looked up your skirt and they've seen everything there is to see.  _Niles exits.  Frasier sits with his knees tightly together.  FADE TO:_ **FRASIER CRANE TO BLOCK**  _Scene Eight - Frasier's Apartment. It's nighttime, and Frasier is sitting on the couch, watching a video of the commercial.  Martin enters._

speaker: Martin
text: What are you still doing up? [_sees Frasier rewinding the video_] Oh geez, you're not watching the tape of that dumb commercial again!

speaker: Frasier
text: I can't get it off my mind.  Did I do the right thing?

speaker: Martin
text: Of course you did.  Freddie's gonna thank you for it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Here, watch it with me one more time.  _He starts the video.  The commercial consists of two nuts arguing until the monkey nut opens up, revealing... Dr. Joyce Brothers._

speaker: Advert
text: Stop!  You're both nuts!  I'm noted psychologist Dr. Joyce Brothers and I'm here to tell you that I'm just crazy about Emery's Nuts.  So if you're crazy about nuts too, pick up a can of Emery's today.  Emery's - the nut lover's nut.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_switching off video_] I suppose you're right, dad.  Freddie will thank me.  Dr. Joyce is his favorite psychologist.

speaker: Martin
text: You know, Dr. Joyce is pretty good.  I remember her from "Hollywood Squares."  She was always under Charlie Weaver.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no.  Charlie Weaver was always on the bottom.

speaker: Martin
text: No, I don't think so.  Let's see, Paul Lynn was in the middle, George Goldblum was under him, and... where was Wally Cox?

speaker: Frasier
text: Wally Cox.  Uh, upper left, next to Rosemarie Dubarr.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, right...
